properties.Title: Tomokanga (Portal)
properties.ArtistCompany: Ariki Creative and Pixel Productions Ltd
properties.Description: Tomokanga is created from LED panels that form the legs and arches welcoming visitors into Victoria Square. This digital artwork invites you to walk through it as you enter and exit the festival, and like entering a portal, pass from one state to another. A newly commissioned sound work, Hine-O-Te-Wai Otakaro composed by Mahina-Ina Kingi-Kaui accompanies the second portal in Tomokanga.
properties.LinkText: Learn more about the artwork and music.

properties.Title: Tomokanga (Portal)
properties.ArtistCompany: Ariki Creative and Pixel Productions Ltd
properties.Description: Tomokanga is created from LED panels that form the legs and arches welcoming visitors into Victoria Square. This digital artwork invites you to walk through it as you enter and exit the festival, and like entering a portal, pass from one state to another.

properties.Title: Ururangi Pou
properties.ArtistCompany: Ariki Creative and Pixel Productions Ltd
properties.Description: One of the stars in the Matariki cluster, Ururangi (Merope), meaning winds of the sky, is the star linked to atmospheric conditions, winds, and the sky.  For Tīrama Mai light is projected onto this symbolic and significant pou by local artist and master carver Riki Manuel, telling us of the battle between Tāwhirimātea and his brothers and the anger Tāwhirimātea felt for the separation of his parents, Papatūānuku and Ranginui.

properties.Title: Purapura Whetū
properties.ArtistCompany: Ariki Creative and Pixel Productions Ltd
properties.Description: Purapura Whetū acknowledges the abundance of whetū in our night sky. Taking patterns from Ngā Whetū, Ngā Manu and cross-stitching them together, the digital techniques used by Ariki Creative to animate the images, reference the way in which tukutuku are woven together.  Keep an eye out for other tukutuku references throughout Victoria Square – you might see more, here and there.

properties.Title: Pāhekoheko (Kinect Interactive)
properties.Description: Stand in front of the screen and move your arms around. See your energy in colour.

properties.Title: Ata Pūao (First Light)
properties.ArtistCompany: Hōhua Kurene and Spectrum Lighting and Sound
properties.Description: Photographer Hōhua Kurene brings us Aoraki Mt Cook at dawn. The stars are still visible, and the air bites as the sun rises in the east. Each Pou will be covered on 2 sides in a corner arrangement with LED panels.

properties.Title: Kā Ata Mariko (Trees Interactive)
properties.Description: Spectrum Lighting and Sound encourage you to look up and marvel at the trees offering a vibrant and magical viewpoint of this area, rich in old, large trees that make up our Garden City.

properties.Title: Muramura te Mahara (Kāi Tahu Origin Story)
properties.ArtistCompany: The Light Site with Ariki Creative
properties.Description: Actors: Ana Te Uruti and Taane Flanagan. Script by Hori Te Ariki Mataki with support from Lynne Harata Te-Aika. Sound mix (Multi-Media Team): Damian Rarere.  Back by popular demand, this 21m-long illuminated tunnel runs alongside the Bowker Fountain in Victoria Square. Walk through the dazzling light display and immerse yourself in the Kāi Tahu origin story, Te Waitatatanga Mai o Ngā Atua by Kāi Tahu rakatira, Mataiaha Tiramōrehu.

properties.Title: Matariki
properties.ArtistCompany: Art Fetiche and M?ui Studios Aotearoa
properties.Description: Matariki appears as a hologram of a powerful māmā looking over her 8 tamariki — Pōhutukawa, Tupuānuku, Tupuārangi, Waitī, Waitā, Waipuna-ā-rangi, Ururangi, Hiwa-i-te-rangi.

properties.Title: Kā Pakiwaitara (Mitre10 Storytelling Zone)
properties.Description: Live readings of Matariki stories and Māori legends will be performed around the Ngā Kōrero Pakiwaitara (Matariki storytelling zone), throughout the weekends of the festival, from 6-8pm. In between Pūrākau, come and enjoy the sounds of local musician Henare Kaa, with newly commissioned Waiata, Hiwa I Te Rangi and Ōtautahi and Upoko Upoko Whiti Te Rā, composed by local musician and teacher, Kommi Tamati-Elliffe.  Do you have a favourite Matariki story? Ka rawe! Share it with your friends and or family.

properties.Title: Te Arawhiti (Light Bridge)
properties.Description: Te Arawhiti is a colourful illumination of the Victoria Square Bridge, which crosses Ōtākaro in the middle of the square.   Can you see any Tuna swimming beneath it? Tuna are kaitiaki, or guardians, of our streams, rivers and lakes, and are used as environmental indicators.

properties.Title: He Ua Tūrama (Light Rain)
properties.Description: Vertical rods hanging from one of the many large trees in Victoria Square encourage you to look up! Trees are a vital component of our world for many reasons. They cool the air, stabilise soils and provide food and habitats for birds, insects and wildlife. They also greatly contribute to cleaning our air by sucking up and storing carbon.

properties.Title: Te Atamira (Performance Zone)
properties.Description: Throughout the course of Tīrama Mai, entertainment from across Ōtautahi is here to enliven your evening on Friday, Saturday and Sunday – from kapa haka to fire poi, we think you’ll find something you like.

properties.Title: Ngao Matariki - Ka Tīaho, Ka Tūmanako
properties.ArtistCompany: Art Fetiche and Ariki Creative, Te Aotahi Rice Edwards, Eli Taueki and Hori Te Ariki Mataki with Rima composed by Kommi Tamati-Elliffe
properties.Description: In traditional Māori carving a toki (adze) is used to carve through wood or stone. Ngao Matariki - Ka Tīaho, Ka Tūmanako utilises light, instead of a toki, by cutting through the darkness of each cube revealing colourful and important tohu (symbols) of Puaka Matariki, like Te Kore – Te Pō. Te Ao Marama, Te Kete Mātauraka and Mahika Kai.

properties.Title: Kā Pakiwaituhi
properties.Description: An animated reel using the characters already created by Māui Studios, Matariki gives us some insight into the stars and their significance to Kāi Tahu in this short animation.

properties.Title: Pōhutukawa
properties.Description: Pōhutukawa (Sterope/Asterope) is the eldest child of Matariki. Her name is associated with the ancient Pōhutukawa tree that sits on the edge of Te Rerenga Wairua and is where our wairua goes once it leaves our body and travels through Te Ara Wairua to Pōhutukawa.

properties.Title: Te Awa Tūrama  (Radiant River)
properties.ArtistCompany: Installation by Season Event Design-ETS with Music by Motte
properties.Description: Follow Te Awa Tūrama, with mesmerising lights along the riverbank of Ōtākaro accompanied by the serene and mesmerising music by Ōhinehou Lyttelton-based artist, Motte.  Do you recognise the birdsong in the music? See if you can identify them.

properties.Title: Te Poi me Te Tapu o te Mārama (Move to your own beat)
Te Poi me Te Tapu o te Mārama (Move to your own beat)
Te Poi me Te Tapu o te Mārama (Move to your own beat)
Te Poi me Te Tapu o te Mārama (Move to your own beat)
Te Poi me Te Tapu o te Mārama (Move to your own beat)
Tirama Mai
properties.Description: Thanks to the team at The Light Site this is the spot to take that perfect photo in front of our bold and beautiful Tīrama Mai sign. Gather your whānaunga and take a photo to remember what you did this Matariki.

properties.Title: Nga Whetu, Nga Manu (The Stars Are Like Birds)
properties.ArtistCompany: ILLUMINATI - Abe Fisher and Ariki Creative - Taane Flannagan
properties.Description: Ngā Whetu, Ngā Manu signifies the ten stars in the night sky that mark the beginning of the new year celebrations: Puanga and the Matariki star cluster - Matariki, Pōhutukawa, Waitī, Waitā, Waipuna-ā-rangi, Tupuānuku, Tupuārangi, Ururangi, and Hiwa-i-te-rangi. Each star has a unique indigenous narrative and seasonal reference, such as mahinga kai, the traditional foods, their sources, and methods of food gathering.

properties.Title: Taiwhaka Kai (Food court area)
properties.Description: Kerry Ford of Foodies has pulled together an amazing selection of kai to tantalise your tastebuds.   Mid-winter was a time of rest and relaxation for Māori. The food storage pits and houses were full, and the busy harvest season was over. Food and feasting was a central element in Matariki, and people came together to share the fruits of the harvest. Other forms of celebration included music, dance, art and spending time with one another. Gather your whanau together, eat some tasty kai and have a celebration together.

properties.Title: Mana Wahine
properties.Description: Referencing the eight generations of wāhine in Harrington’s whānau to her namesake, Ema Turumeke, KAKANA (Team Player) is a sculpture of grand, bright and luminous forms, huddled together as if bodies sharing secrets, knowledge or sacred information.

properties.Title: He Hahana o Toi Ōtautahi (Toi Ōtautahi Lightboxes)
properties.ArtistCompany: Individual Lightboxes by Conor Clarke, Simon Kaan and Kim Lowe
properties.Description: Lightboxes.
